Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A customer urgently needs their delivery by the promised time window, such as groceries for dinner
Story: I was halfway through my delivery route when I stopped by the office to drop off a package. As I waited for the recipient to sign, I overheard an acquaintance, Mark, making a snide remark about our colleague, Sarah, criticizing her recent project. Mark turned to me, expecting me to join in or at least nod in agreement. As an acquaintance, I knew I shouldn’t gossip or speak negatively about others, but Mark’s expectant look made it hard to stay neutral. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a notification: a customer was anxiously tracking their grocery delivery, messaging that they needed it for dinner and couldn’t afford a delay. I felt the pressure mounting—if I stayed to handle the awkward conversation with Mark, I risked being late and letting down the customer. But if I left abruptly, I might seem rude or complicit in the gossip. My mind raced, torn between the demands of being a considerate acquaintance and a reliable delivery person, unsure which expectation I should meet.
